Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as bcb0ab4f1e933795e53da7c28ca75382c94f9af9
What happens if the old password is incorrect?
In this case there will be error pop-up with a message about wrong credentials
Does it logs out current session in this case?
No, the session stays the same
Seems okay to me, modulo my observations in the comments.  But I am not a web application developer.
I think this added by mistake, we are already checking this.form.newPassword in the previous statement?

I am not familiar with the web application, but I understand this code checks if the old password is correct. I have two independent observations:
1. This change is only at the web application layer, so it provides additional security only at that layer.  In particular, the underlying Redfish API (PATCH ... "Password") still works (with no old password needed).
2. If the login is successful, it creates a new session.  Please either delete the session in this case, or use some other way to determine if authentication worked (for example, GET /redfish/v1/AccountService using BasicAuth, which does not create a session).

For 1, we approached the DMTF about this question, and they don't believe it is an issue as the current authentication must be provided (either through basic auth or the session token) to change the password.  Our conclusion is that the security gap is only in the web UI that can leave a session unattended.
If Current password entered is correct and New password gets updated successfully, then all current sessions (for that user) gets logged out or not? Do we get redirected to login screen?
We are not redirected to login screen, but the session changes. Soon I will use another endpoint that does not change session
Is it better to call it as "Current Password"?

Can you add more info here? 
It looks like you are deleting all sessions after changing the password? Even sessions not tied to the user? Why?
@Kiran, you can also add your "Signed-off-by" line, here.

so this deletes all sessions? 
deleteAllSessions might be a better name but more importantly, why do this? Why delete all sessions? Doesn't this impacts other users (e.g. let's assume users Admin and ReadOnly, if Admin changed thier password, isn't Readonly also impacted?)

I have updated the patch to delete the password changed user's sessions only. And it won't affect the other user's sessions.

changed the function name to "deleteAllSessions" and added the comments also.
Isn't this also a race condition between when the current session gets deleted and when it loses permission to delete the rest of the sessions?
Updated the patch to handle all other password changed user's session delete operations in promises. once all promises are resolved, then only the current session gets deleted.

This may have morphed from a session issue:

Originally, all we needed to do was check the current password authentication before proceeding with the password change.  Damian chose to do this by starting a new Redfish Session.  The problem was, on success, you were now left with two active sessions.

I believe he originally planned to only delete the new session.  There is another security issue that still needs to be discussed on whether all sessions should close on password change, and this patch set may have been tainted from that separate issue.

If we can get away with just deleting the new session or finding a way to authenticate the current password without starting a new session, I think it may be better.  Then we can leave the "delete all sessions" question to that discussion.

As a side thought.  The new session would be left inactive and bmcweb will close it automatically on timeout.  Is there any harm in leaving the extra session open and just letting it time out on its own?

> If we can get away with just deleting the new session or finding a way to authenticate the current password without starting a new session, I think it may be better. 

+1. 

>  The new session would be left inactive and bmcweb will close it automatically on timeout.

Agree. 

>  Is there any harm in leaving the extra session open and just letting it time out on its own?

I will let Joseph weigh in since he raised this but then it shows up in the sessionService and on the session page of the GUI. I don't find this the end of the world but unexpected. I find this less annoying that the current patch which deletes all the sessions of this user and has a race condition.

I updated the patch to validate the current password, after success allowing the user to change the password and log out of the current session.

As you mentioned in the above comments, we will look into deleting all the password changed sessions as a separate issue.
So the current patch set just leaves around the session used to test if the old password was correct?

> If we can get away with just deleting the new session or finding a way to authenticate the current password without starting a new session, I think it may be better.

I have debugged further and found a way to check the current password without starting a new session. I have written one POST method API call, and from that, we will get the current password and username from the user. Using pamAuthenticateUser, we can check whether the current password is correct or not.

With the success of that API call, we can proceed to update the password. If the API call fails, we don't need to proceed further to update the password.

Thoughts?

Are there any concerns with pushing this change as-is to mitigate the security issue and leave the duplicate session open until it times out?  We can then continue to improve the solution in later patches.
Ping again.  Any concerns with moving this change forward?
If there is no further concerns, shall we move forward to get +2?
Sure. I am fine with that.
I am fine moving forward with this.
